reviewText: This 2005 live concert in Budokan Hall,Tokyo is their first reunion tour since Rob's departure in the early 90's.One reason to own this release is the fact that PRIEST doesn't have many video documentaries to offer their fans-whether they be clips or concerts.Another reason is the show itself which exhibits the band's outstanding musicianship in the genre for over 30 years.Supported with spectacular lighting and stage design,PRIEST performs explosive head-banging and heart-pounding metal for over 2 hours.Despite some minor shortcomings in the show,the PRIEST is STILL the gods of metal !
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was really keen when Angel of Retribution came out.Not only was it Priest's "reunion" album, but it felt more like a natural continuation of the band (vs. something like "KISS: Psycho Circus").The songs were epic.  The writing amazing.  Rob Halford...were the HECK have you BEEN?!?This DVD more than anything shows that, while Ripper Owens is an AMAZING talent, Priest can't be Priest without Rob.  There are over TWENTY tracks in this concert, all of which the band totally nail.The only downside of this disc, and it's no reason to take away a star, is that the effects are diminished from previous shows, and Rob is way less active.  I do miss the "Defenders of the Faith" type of "motion" sets.  Priest seems content lately with changing background panels/flags instead of moving props - a shame.That aside, the show looks great, sounds great, reunites Priest in Japan, and proves the Priest are indeed Metal Gods.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Kudos first of all to the filming crew, film editing crew and sound techs.  They did an outstanding job.  I have over a hundred concert DVD's and have seen few of this quality.  It is no letdown.  I have been anticipating this DVD since I heard it would be released during their concert in  Albuquerque, New Mexico in late June. It is awesome.  Not having features was expected because of the lower cost but you can catch a current feature of the band  on the DVD side of the Angel of Retribution CD  and this is an excellent price on amazon.com for it as well.

reviewText: This reunion has to be one of the best in recent times..Preist is back with their original lineup with over thirty years in the business.The boys are all pushing way over 50 and can still rock, Rob Halford has patched up his difference and the 'screamer' has never sounded better, they peform all thier classics before a packed Budokan (Japanese)crowd.The magic pair of Axemen Tipton and Downing played flawlessly ..Preist were supporting their new album Angel of retribution  an album metal fan's needed... to be reminded what metal is all about and how it should be done!The production is great as the Dvd is perfect!Definitely a collecters item for any real Metal fan!Twisted Sister recently reunited and also put on a memorable show at Waken in Germany (great performance) by the original SMF's!

reviewText: This concert is full of energy. They get the Japanese crowd is so revved and every song is taken to the hilt. Rob sounds great. He sings "Another thing comin" on top of a Harley and on "Painkiller" he is so spent he lays on top of a monitor and sings. He is covered from head to toe in heavy black leather. He must have lost about five pounds under those lights. The guitars aren't as wild as they were in "Fuel for Life" but KK and Glenn definitely hold their own and they rock. Camerawork is excellent. Great set list. This is more enjoyable than "Fuel for Life". I was really impressed and it sparked my interest in Priest again.

reviewText: I don't know what some people are whining about! They have a problem with their equipment! On mine it sounds great! Halford sings a lot better than on the Electric Eye DVD (from 20 years ago!). And he finally looks like a  heavy metal singer. And the set list is so much better. I like Ripper Owens a lot  (watch his stuff with Iced Earth, it's great!) but I cannot place Live in London above Rising in the East.  Overall, a great  DVD from one of the greatest metal bands! It's so great to have them still around making great CDs!

reviewText: I really enjoy this concert, and watching the band rock on with so many great songs. I love the 3 options of audio to your liking. Yes, everyone is getting older but they still Rock the House down. I have All of the Priest albums considering they are one of my all time favorite band. The stage is Huge and I feel they could've done a lot more to the stage and with props and stuff. I did like the Harley Davidson coming out of the smoke. I love watching the cute oriental girls head banging and rocking out with the songs, and damn, they are so adorable and cute. The crowd was having a great time and everyone was singing and waving their hands around, so that is always a great crowd to have. I love the several Heavy costumes that Rob Halford are wearing and the way he walks around the stage, he OWNS that stage. Great show

reviewText: Performance is great , shame the dvd is only avgPICTURE 5/10 SOUND 6.5/10 EXTRAS 0/0I thought the live in london was a better done dvd , the picture and sound were far better. The camara work on this is alright , the actual picture is not very clear, i dont know if its the effects or the lights which spoil it.Compare OZZY AT THE BODOKEN , a brilliant dvd ( probably the best so far) but the performance was just good. This dvd is only avg but the band performance is great, the band has still got it without a doubt.Could have been so much better with a decent production.Ive got probably 50 heavy metal dvds and this would rate around the middle,  OZZY ATHE BODOKEN, IRON MAIDEN IN RIO, (EDITING DOES NOT WORRY ME) MOTLEY CRUE LEWD AND CRUED and NICKELBACK AT HOME are the best ive seen. reviewText: I had a chance to see this tour in person, but circumstances beyond my control prevented me from attending. I seriously regret that. At least I have this DVD as a document of Rob Halford's triumphant return to Priest. This DVD sounds fantastic. And Rob sounds better than ever. The band sounds tight and looks happy to be playing together again. The set list is a virtual "best-of" of some of the greatest metal tunes ever written. Put it in, turn it up, and ROCK.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Opening with the classic double punch of `The Hellion/Electric Eye,' you know that this concert is going to be good.The band do their best to mix a diverse career spanning set list with playing all their biggest hits and do a pretty successful job, managing to cover a full five songs from their then new `Angel of Retribution,' album with their big hits like `Breaking the Law,' `Living After Midnight,' and `You've Got Another Thing Coming,' while still playing at least one song from their less famous `Point of Entry,' `Turbo,' and `Ram It Down,' albums.Musically, the band are on fire, with impressive guitar soloing, energetic on stage performances and drummer Scott Travis playing songs harder, with confidence and authority that makes them sound that much heavier and tighter. The band are playing on a fairly large stage with elaborate set pieces, risers and of course, the famous motorcycle.Some fans have made a lot of complaints about Rob Halford's performance here, but with the sole exception of the vocals on the track `Painkiller,' (which, as it happens has impossibly difficult vocals to begin with) I think these complaints are pretty off the mark.If you need proof that Rob can still reach those high notes see the `You're Possessing Me,' scream in `A Touch of Evil' or indeed the entire performance of the fast and high pitched `Riding on the Wind.'Furthermore Rob's whole on-stage attitude is a winner, seeming genuinely pleased each and every time the crowd gets a sing along moment correct, adding little Robotic Walk gestures to `Metal Gods,' and generally looking like he's giving it his all, to the point where he is sweating and red in the face, not because he can't hack it, but rather because he's giving it his very all.Even if you do for some reason take exception with Rob, there is simply no denying the performances of Glen, Scott, Ian and Mr. Downing who all blast away like a well oiled machine, but with the energy of a much younger band.In terms of camera, editing, sound and mix there really isn't anything to complain about, everything is handled well and the whole package is as slick and professional as you would hope for from a band of their size.Overall this is a great looking and great sounding DVD from Judas Priest and that alone should have you interested, add to that an interesting set list and dismiss the complaints about Rob and you should find `Rising In The East,' a really worthy addition to your collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This concert in Japan was filmed two weeks before I saw Priest play in St. Paul. It is truly inspiring that Judas Priest can continue to put on solid classic metal concerts while in their mid-50s. They included several cuts from their new CD (Angel of Retribution - a fantastic release), which keeps this DVD from being a mere rehash of the greatest hits.It's not perfect. Painkiller doesn't come across with the power I expected it to. Glenn seems a little low in the mix. Rob doesn't have the same magnetic stage presence he used to (but still gives a good performance). There are no songs from Defenders of the Faith (get rid of Hot Rockin' and put in the Sentinel or Freewheel Burning). But these are very trivial items that do not really detract from the whole package.Overall, this is the best live priest video available with the exception of the '82 Memphis show - that is a solid five stars but this one comes close.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great sellection of songs, great show, great musically and I hate to say, so, so vocally. I LOVE this band and have for over 30 years but Rob has shown his range is not what it used to be. His stage presence is still one of the all time best in metal, BUT, the studio may be his best spot now. It pains me to say this because of my love for the band but I can not lie. You'll see the change in the range and some difficulty, though still smooth, to find some of the high notes. Overall this is another very good Priest live dvd but know of this and enjoy it for what it is.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The performance is killer and there are a gazillion other reviews here that attest to it so I'm not delving into it any further. What I want to do instead is bring attention upon some flaws that almost ruined this DVD for me :1- For a 2005 video, this does not seem to have been mastered from a great def source. First off and oddly enough, the aspect ratio is 4:3. I personally love the vintage format and maybe it was shot that way on purpose but I know most people said WTF when their flatscreens exhibited black sidebars. The variable pic bitrate hovers closely around 7 Mbps; not bad for standard resolution but I have seen 2-hour dvds with 9-11 Mbps. Again, maybe the source did not call for a better mastering because it was limited by original quality. I watched it on a big CRT TV and still could spot minor artifacting here and there.2- The PCM audio mix : Weak; little bottom end (and I have a big sub I had to crank A LOT to get punch from the drums). Also the guitar on the right channel is HALF as loud as the one on the left one, which forced me to switch to mono for an even soundscape. This was effective but the twin-axe attack was weakened in the process. At times, esp when both guitarrists were riffing without their volume pedals engaged, the guitars were a faint drone at the back of the mix. Same with Rob's voice; pity, coz he's still reaching those impossible highs after all these years. All in all, this can be made to sound pretty good despite the flaws, and it's the Priest FFS !!! They managed to put out a MASSIVE wall of sound anyways !!Well I'm glad I was given this as a present or I would be very angry. It is a piece of history and a keeper anyway. Buy at your own risk or get it very cheap.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Marcus Damanda "author of The Forever Show"
reviewText: I've seen Judas Priest live and in person for the "Turbo", "Ram It Down", "Painkiller", Ozzfest, and "Angel" tours, and--even though they've always delivered the goods--they've absolutely never been this good before. Any fan of Judas Priest with any perspective simply has to acknowledge that while Halford's voice has solidly endured, the guitar playing of Glenn Tipton and, especially, K.K. Downing has positively blossomed into riffs and tears they could not have dreamed of playing back in, say, 1979. Travis, their American drummer since "Painkiller", never misses a beat, yet he plays the old songs faithfully (something he could do, I'm sure, with one hand and one foot amputated).The set list on this Budokon show is representative of Priest's entire career, including most of what you would want to hear and a few surprises (such as "Hot Rockin'" and "I'm a Rocker"). But, really, even though I grew up on the albums "Screaming for Vengeance" and "Defenders of the Faith"--after which they fell into a long slump--it's the performance of newer monster jams, especially "Hellrider", that really blew me away.Whether you're a new fan or an old one, whether you're in the camp of the Priest faithful or just love your metal hard and heavy, this is the strongest concert DVDs to come out in a long, long time.(This review has been posted by Marcus Damanda, author of the vampire novel "Teeth:  Horror Fantasy.")
summary: Some Things, Like Judas Priest, Just Get Better With Age

reviewText: Yep, Metaldiva witnessed this live from the 32nd row in 2005 at DTE Music Theater and it was a blast.  It would be nice if in the second printing that the sound get a tweak or two but the visual quality was the same as live.  This was filmed so it does have the filmed quality (more matte) but it was true to the performance.  The fellas can still rock with the best of them and the show was everything you expect from Priest, powerful and strong.  Rob is still wailing strong and although he might sing a note or two a tad lower, he maintains one of the most operatically beautiful and powerful voices in rock.  After 35 years of Japanese concerts from Budokan and the likes, Metaldiva cannot get over the crazy enthusiasm that the Eastern audiences have for our western artists.  The cameo of the weeping fan during an intro to a song later in the DVD was something else.  This is fun to watch and a "must-add" to your collection.  It is also a great way for fans to "share the love" with the newer generations.  Yes, Metaldiva did take her two little headbanging Metalbabies to the concert and was not the only one.  We sat in front of a dozen families, and everyone rocked themselves happy.  Metaldiva Sez:  Great DVD, wish the sound was better, but it is a must buy. Capturing classic Priest for posterity.* Cheers to the band for the recent Rock Honors as well!
summary: Saw the Concert and This Captures the Energy

reviewText: Incredible is the only way to describe this DVD. Every song is done really well some as good as their albums versions, many better and maybe one or two that aren't as good, but by no means are bad. Rob Halford still really has it and can still sing the high stuff, though in some places on this dvd he doesn't go as high as he can. I assume he does this because of the extended set list and doesn't want to wear himself out. But I don't see how anybody can say he's not as good as he used to be though, because I think he is way better than he used to be and he sings in a lot better voice that's far more experienced than before.  I saw them live this past summer and every song was better than it's album version and he was hitting high notes that could blow your head off. So, if your a fan of priest you can not go wrong with this dvd because it really is incredible and a great offering to us fans.

reviewText: Rob Halford reunited with Judas Priest...ignore the "not their best" comments and realize that a world with this legendary band intact and performing new music is better than a world without one. From the blistering opening of "Hellion / Electric Eye" to the closer "You've Got Another Thing Comin'," this is a Metal dream come true. You can see the joy on the faces of every band member as they pound Japan's Budokan Arena into a fine powder. My response to anyone who moans "Oh, they're not as GOOD as they were in the EIGHTIES" is this: IT'S NOT THE EIGHTIES! This is an aggressively played, joyous concert...one which transcends time and self-appointed "critics" of the band. The fans know...read the four and five star reviews. That's where you'll find the truth about this concert.
summary: Beautifully filmed, a real "live" feel, and rocks like a mother.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Always thought that front-man Rob Halford would, in time reunite with Judas Priest. It was well WORTH the wait. A total of 23 Priest metal gems, performed and presented here for your viewing pleasure in living (sometimes split-screen) color. Show took place May, 2005 at the Budokan-Tokyo. Great picture and sound quality. Few bands play metal 'live' like these British gentlemen do. Great to watch, specially on a giant-screen TV. The tunes you remember are here, like the usual two openers (no complaint there) "Hellion", "Electric Eye", "Ripper" (the way Halford dresses here, he could play the part of 'The Ripper' in a horror movie), "Hot Rockin'" (one of my personal favorites), "Breaking The Law", "Turbo Lover", the ultimate '80's metal anthem "Living After Midnight" and "You've Got Another Thing Coming". Not really at all familiar with any new material off their most recent 'Angel Of Retribution' CD. Notice this DVD has no special features. That's okay, I mean - who has the time? An absolute must-have. Highly recommended.
summary: Judas Priest - 'Rising In The East' (Rhino/Wea) Running time: 110 minutes
Title: N/A

reviewText: With Rob Halford back in the fold, and last year's release of the comeback album of the year with "Angel of Retribution", Judas Priest is back, and this concert DVD is proof that they still have it.  Rising in the East finds Priest performing in Tokyo's famed Budokan to a roaring crowd, and surprising enough the band still has energy to burn even all these years later.  The track list is basically perfect for even novice Priest fans, including songs you'd expect ("Breaking the Law", "Living After Midnight", "You've Got Another Thing Coming"), fan favorite classics ("Beyond the Realms of Death", "Diamonds and Rust", "Victim of Changes"), and new songs from their recent album (the pounding "Judas Rising", "Revolution", "Deal With the Devil"), which is a nice mix.  Halford still sounds great, and the guitar combo of K.K. Downing and Glenn Tipton still packs a punch.  The sound quality is excellent, and the video quality is solid, but the only downside of the DVD is that there aren't any extras included, but the fact that this concert DVD is as great as it is should be more than enough to satisfy any Priest fan.  All in all, Rising in the East is as essential as it gets.

reviewText: Well...I have very mixed feelings about this disc. I LOVE Judas Priest. As I am 43 years old, I remember buying Rocka Rolla on LP when it first was released. I have purchased every recording since then. Up until now there was always one thing I could count on...Rob Halford would always be great. You could question songs, lyrics etc but Rob's vocals would always be clear, loud and high! With the release of Rising In The East, I no longer can take for granted that,the vocals that have driven this great band, will be up to par with his great past. And isn't that really the issue here? We will ALWAYS compare Rob's vocals to...well...HIMSELF! He had always delivered before and we EXPECT them to be great because they always had been.Rob is old...So am I as a matter of fact...but we ALL get old. Just not in public with huge expectations on our shoulders. NEVER in all the years I have heard Priest would I have expected all the lower ranges, the lack of screaming, lack of sustain, (Painkiller is PAINFUL to watch!!) and well..OZZY like way he just paces back and forth like an...old man. He NEVER did that stuff...NEVER! And I agree with another review..LOSE standing infront of the prompter! You can't remember your own words??? Ouch! That is embarrassing.  Again, you never needed that before!The question is, What happened? I saw him 3 times on his Resurrection and Crucible tours and he was amazing! Even though he was still just pacing back and forth, his voice was insane! Was he tired, recorded too late in the tour? I don't know but if you are going to record and then release a recording, shouldn't you have the best vocals possible? Just wondering.I must comment at this time about Tim "the Ripper" Owens. I want to say right now that he did an AMAZING job while in the band! His voice was as much like (old) Halford's as you could ever find and he gave all the old songs a huge kick in the backside. (Just listen to Rapid Fire on Metal Meltdown '98 WOW!) The problem with the band during this period is very simple and basic. They tuned down (for easier vocal ranges) and lost that power and clarity you get when you are in standard A440 tuning. The detuning left the band muddy and without definition. IF they had played in the standard tuning (as with Rob), things might have been different. I would have been fine with Tim in the band for good as I really, REALLY enjoyed Rob's solo work. THANKS TIM!!This DVD is great on so many levels. I have to say that Tipton and K.K. sound HUGE, POWERFUL and AMAZING. Never before has the twin attack sounded more aggressive and pure. For that alone, this DVD gets at least 3 stars. If the singer was a total joke, I could love this just for the guitars.I will now do something that I have never done before..I think this is the best Scott Travis has ever sounded with Judas Priest! I am a professional drummer and have been playing for over 30 years. I am in the minority here but I have always loved Les Binks the most, Dave Holland second and then Scott Travis. I was really wanting Bobby Jarzombek to join the band when Rob came back. But that is just me wishingout loud. He is the BEST drummer Halford has ever played with PERIOD! I rant...sorry.. But on this Travis is perfect in tempo, style and feel..GREAT DRUMMING FOR CERTAIN!!I must also make one more huge complaint...WHAT!! NO DEFENDERS OF THE FAITH??? That is like seeing Deep Purple and them playing nothing from Machine Head or Iron Maiden with nothing from Number of the Beast! You can not leave out that recording! There I feel better...well sort of ..I for the most part really enjoy this disc. I saw the show here in Chicago and Rob was still singing things down (Exciter just doesn't sound right..sorry guys) but was still screaming! I like the staging and the lighting. The sound quality is outstanding but Rob is a little too far back in the mix.In closing, this is a great collection for any fan. Just do not expect to hear the Rob from Unleashed in the East, or from the Fuel for Life Tour. It appears that you can't even expect the Halford from the Resurrection era either. As long as we, the fans, except that our heroes DO get old we will be ok with this DVD. But, it is our human nature to want the old, younger and stronger versions of our heroes! Just ask the fans in Washington what they "expected" of the great Michael Jordan when he came to town!Living up to the past is hard and cruel...it is harder when it is YOUR past that you are fighting! Judas Priest is fighting their own past! And I am afraid that it is catching up to them.Rock on!Peace!PJ
summary: Finally showing their age...reflections of a fan...

reviewText: The boys were up for the taping of this performance. Rob Halford is on; KK Downing's and Glenn Tipton's guitar playing is tight as the studio versions of the songs. Ian Hill rocks and Scott Travis' drumming is up front and quite impressive.The difference between the live performance in this release versus the 1986 performance included with the 2003 Electric Eye music video collection DVD is that before the boys took the stage for this performance at the Budokan in Tokyo, Japan, they must have agreed to try to be as true to the studio versions as Rob's voice would allow (give him a break; remember he's been taxing his vocal chords and hitting the high notes in Victim of Changes for like thirty years!).The sound quality is great. If you've got surround sound you're in for a pounding Heavy Metal treat. The picture is great. And the footage doesn't jump around all the time; the camera gives you more than the typical music video four seconds before jumping to another angle, so you can really feel like you're watching the show live.Any Priest fan should not pass on this DVD. I'm telling you, the chills were non-stop for me; I couldn't believe they included The Ripper and Exciter. And you get (just about) every other rocker that you really want to see. In other words, Rising in the East is a compilation of terrific live performances of the following:1. HELLION2. ELECTRIC EYE3. METAL GODS4. RIDING ON THE WIND5. RIPPER6. TOUCH OF EVIL7. JUDAS RISING8. REVOLUTION9. HOT ROCKIN'10. BREAKING THE LAW11. I'M A ROCKER12. DIAMONDS AND RUST13. WORTH FIGHTING FOR14. DEAL WITH THE DEVIL15. BEYOND THE REALMS OF DEATH16. TURBO LOVER17. HELLRIDER18. VICTIM OF CHANGES19. EXCITER20. PAINKILLER21. HELL BENT FOR LEATHER22. LIVING AFTER MIDNIGHT23. YOU'VE GOT ANOTHER THING COMINGThere are no special features here, and that was somewhat disappointing. But believe me this front row seat to a performance by the Metal Gods is well worth it by itself. Buy it.

reviewText: Priest... back with Rob? I'll take it.This is an absolute classic, and as always, the Japanese rock audiences prove to be among the best in the world. This reunion has been a long time coming, but it was well worth the wait.The band are as tight as ever, the sound and futuristic lighting are fantastic, and Rob is his own Terminator self. No disrespect to Mr. Owens, who did a great job, but this is the real McCoy.Excellent track selection, great visuals, but no extras, alas, which is disappointing after 30 years of Priest classics. I saw them six times when I still lived in the UK, and they are as hot as ever.Essential for any Priest fan.

reviewText: I thought you all should know that I am taking off half a star because of the bad sound quality.  For most of the songs I can hardly hear Rob Halford's voice because it is too low in the mix.  The same goes for the lead guitars at times.  Now I attended a concert for this tour and it was amazingly loud and crisp and I could hear Rob's high screams as loud and powerful as ever.  Judas Priest are aging guys but that doesn't mean they can't play very loud and fast as is displayed on this DVD.  Also Judas Priest are The Pioneers of metal right along with Black Sabbath.  The only difference is that Priest progressed from their vintage 70s metal sound that Sabbath invented and improved that by speeding up the tempos, playing more intricate guitar leads, and adding Rob halford to the mix.  I have never seen any singer including King Diamond, Ozzy or Geoff Tate hit as many ear splitting high notes as Rob Halford - he truly is a one of a kind vocalist and not just a flashy leather wearing tuff guy.  For the most part the stage props are basic but great for this tour.  The colorful light show makes up for the basic props.  The band members move about the stage very well for their age and do well at entertaining the audience from start to finish.  Each song is performed very well and the songs off Angel of Retribution sound amazing! Hellrider and Judas Rising are awesome tunes in concert.  I look foward to Judas Priest's concept cd coming out next year!
summary: 4.5 Stars for the Stars of Metal!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Seriously, when watching this DVD hit the lights and turn it up. Everything about this release is great. The track listing, The audio and video production, the slow editing, the low price, and most importantly, THE MUSIC!!! The Priest were really on this night. The Highlight is Beyond The Realms Of Death. I think Halford even sounds great, if he has lost anything it is not real noticable. I will be watching this show over and over and over again. Looking forward to new CD from the boys also...
summary: Turn Out Lights, and Turn Up Your Receiver!!!
